coredata.dc:title: Li ions traffic controller on thin lithium metal anode: Regulating deposition, optimizing and protecting solid electrolyte interphase

coredata.dc:description: The performance of thin lithium metal anodes is affected due to issues that weaken the electrode-electrolyte interphase. In this work, a coating layer serving as a Li+ traffic controller based on hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bis(trifluoromethanesulphonyl)imide ([CTA][TFSI]) and poly (vinylidene difluoride co-hexafluoropropylene) (P(VDF-HFP)) is used to stabilize the thin lithium metal interface. The CTA+ ions in the coating layer can effectively regulate the distribution of Li+ concentration to promote uniform deposition of lithium. The anion of [CTA][TFSI] can optimize solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) with inorganic-rich components, which improve the ionic conductivity and reaction kinetics. Furthermore, the flexible polymer skeleton can fortify the fragile SEI, facilitating the consistent operation of the battery. Due to these improvements, a thin Li metal anode (4 mAh cm−2) with a coating layer in a Li||Li symmetric cell demonstrates a lifespan of 600 h at 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2. Notably, full cells with an ultra-low negative electrode/positive electrode = 1 (N/P = 1) demonstrate a stable performance over 200 cycles and 90 cycles at 0.5C and 1C (1C = 170 mA g−1), respectively.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic illustration of the Li metal anode evolution with and without the Li+ traffic controller. SEM images show the cross-sectional morphology of CPC-50-Li and Cu-Li after 20 cycles.

(a) Ionic conductivities of CTA+ in membranes. (b) 1H NMR spectra of CP-0, CP-50 and [CTA][TFSI]. (c) and (g) are enlarged gray bars of Figure (b). (d) SAXS of CP-50. Protons groups assignment of (e) CTA+ and (f) P(VDF-HFP). (h) FTIR spectra of CP-0 and CP-50 membranes. (i) Linear sweep voltammetry curves of CP-0 and CP-50 at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 under room temperature. (j) Current-time plot of the Li||CP-50||Li cell under an applied potential polarization of 10 mV at room temperature. The inset figure shows the impedance spectra before and after potential polarization at room temperature.

(a) and (b) Interfacial chemistry of Cu-Li and CPC-50-Li revealed by XPS depth profiling. (a) C 1s, F 1s, and S 2p XPS spectra of Cu-Li. (b) C 1s, F 1s, and S 2p XPS spectra of CPC-50-Li. (c) Calculated HOMO/LUMO energy and energy gap (ΔE) of LiTFSI and [CTA][TFSI] molecule. (d) Initial cyclic voltammetry curves for CPC-50 and Cu between 0.01 and 2.5 V with a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s−1.

Electrochemical performances of half cells using different electrodes. (a) Nucleation overpotential. (b) Coulombic efficiencies of Cu, CPC-0, and CPC-50 over cycling at 1.0 mA cm−2. The discharge capacity in each cycle was fixed to 1.0 mAh cm−2. (c) Exchange current density of symmetric cells. (d) Cycling performances of symmetric cells of Cu-Li, CPC-0-Li, and CPC-50-Li with an initial capacity of 4.0 mAh cm−2. (e) Summary of the electrochemical performance of Li symmetric cells (coin cells). Total reversible capacity was calculated by multiplying the cycle number by the deposited Li in one cycle. Finite element analysis of Li+ concentration distribution simulated by COMSOL Multiphysics at t = 2 s during the deposition process for (f) Cu-Li and (g) CPC-50-Li.

Electrochemical performances of full cells. (a) Assembled model of low N/P ratio full cell. (b) Comparison of rate performance between Cu-Li||Li1-xFePO4, CPC-0-Li||Li1-xFePO4 and CPC-50-Li||Li1-xFePO4 and (c) Charge/discharge profiles of 70th cycle. (d) Cycling performance of CPC-50-Li||Li1-xFePO4 at 1C (1C = 170 mA g−1) and (e) Charge/discharge profiles for different cycles. (f) Cycling performance of CPC-50-Li||Li1-xFePO4 at 0.5C. (g) Polarization voltage of charge and discharge in Fig. 5f.

head.ce:title: Li ions traffic controller on thin lithium metal anode: Regulating deposition, optimizing and protecting solid electrolyte interphase

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The performance of thin lithium metal anodes is affected due to issues that weaken the electrode-electrolyte interphase. In this work, a coating layer serving as a Li+ traffic controller based on hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bis(trifluoromethanesulphonyl)imide ([CTA][TFSI]) and poly (vinylidene difluoride co-hexafluoropropylene) (P(VDF-HFP)) is used to stabilize the thin lithium metal interface. The CTA+ ions in the coating layer can effectively regulate the distribution of Li+ concentration to promote uniform deposition of lithium. The anion of [CTA][TFSI] can optimize solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) with inorganic-rich components, which improve the ionic conductivity and reaction kinetics. Furthermore, the flexible polymer skeleton can fortify the fragile SEI, facilitating the consistent operation of the battery. Due to these improvements, a thin Li metal anode (4 mAh cm−2) with a coating layer in a Li||Li symmetric cell demonstrates a lifespan of 600 h at 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2. Notably, full cells with an ultra-low negative electrode/positive electrode = 1 (N/P = 1) demonstrate a stable performance over 200 cycles and 90 cycles at 0.5C and 1C (1C = 170 mA g−1), respectively.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium (Li) metal is regarded as a promising anode material due to its high theoretical capacity and low reduction potential [1,2]. Current research has suggested that Li metal anode can benefit from its high energy density only at low thicknesses (<50 μm), which is termed as a thin Li anode [3]. However, the high reactivity and infinite relative volume change give rise to complex interface problems that hinder the practical application of thin Li metal anode [4,5]. The SEI is the key to overcoming these complex interface problems, but the naturally formed SEI often fails to meet the stability requirement. Moreover, SEI with poor composition usually has low ion diffusion [6,7], which causes uneven distribution of the internal electric field and Li+ concentration. This results in a significant discrepancy in the quantity of Li atoms deposited between the tip and valley of the Li [8]. As a result, dendritic Li is formed at the tip because of the “tip effect”. The dynamic volume change of Li has a strong tendency to cause ruptures in native SEI, which possesses non-uniform mechanical properties [9–11]. Fresh Li exposed at the rupture site becomes a source of Li dendrite growth or SEI reconstruction, giving rise to the accumulation of dead Li (generated by dendritic Li) and SEI on the electrode surface [1]. These issues lead to a large amount of Li loss, especially in the thin Li anode system, which results in a significant degradation of the battery performance.

Several strategies have been proposed to address this problem, including adjusting the porous structures of the anode [12], reducing the nucleation barrier by forming Li alloy [13], rational design of electrolyte [14], and construction of protective coating layers [15]. Although these approaches have made clear breakthroughs in thin Li metal batteries, persistent stability of interface and favorable SEI still need reinforcement. It is insufficient to rely on the electrolyte strategy only, because the SEI is intrinsically brittle and will be damaged from the large volume fluctuation of the Li anode. After repeated deposition of Li on the lithiophilic matrix, the nucleophilic sites are covered and invalidated. Therefore, a flexible artificial SEI that can regulate the uniform deposition of Li, and fortify the SEI could ensure the long-term effectiveness of the thin Li metal anode.

Herein, a multifunctional artificial SEI is constructed using P(VDF-HFP) polymer and [CTA][TFSI]. The artificial SEI is first coated on Cu and then a certain amount of lithium metal is deposited on the Cu to prepare a thin lithium metal anode. The P(VDF-HFP) polymer imparts flexibility to the coating layer such that it can adapt to the electrode deformation and protect the fragile SEI. The [CTA][TFSI] is involved in controlling Li+ path via a self-healing electrostatic shield mechanism [16]. During lithium deposition, the reduction and deposition of Li+ are prevented due to the CTA+ forming a positively charged electrostatic shield over the initial growth tip of the protuberances. Due to this shield, dendrite formation is avoided by facilitating the additional lithium deposition into adjacent regions of the tip [17–19]. In addition, the nonpolar aliphatic chain of CTA+ increases the lithiophobic effect [20,21], which further diverts the concentrated Li+ to adjacent regions. Furthermore, the in-situ formed inorganic-rich SEI on the Li metal as a result of the [CTA][TFSI] priority decomposition imparts the SEI with high ionic conductivity, which also regulates the internal Li+ concentration. Hence, [CTA][TFSI]-P(VDF-HFP) as Li+ traffic controller promotes uniform Li deposition and protects the SEI from cracking during the Li anode volume fluctuation process. Additionally, the potential interference and contamination from moisture can be also reduced due to the hydrophobicity of [CTA][TFSI]. To demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed approach, symmetric cells based on thin Li anode (4 mAh cm−2) and full cells are fabricated with a strict ultra-low N/P = 1. Results show that these cells exhibit a steady cycling behavior, proving that Li+ traffic controller is an effective method to promote the good performance of thin lithium metal anode.

[CTA][TFSI] was fabricated by an anion exchange method. CTAC (purchased from ALADDIN, 97 %) was diluted in distilled water with a concentration of 10 mg mL−1. Subsequently, LiTFSI (purchased from MACKLIN, 99.9 %) aqueous solution with a molar ratio of 1:1 was added drop-wise under magnetic stirring. The white precipitates of [CTA][TFSI] were collected by vacuum filtration and washed with distilled water. Finally, the sample was dried at 80 °C under vacuum for 24 h.

For studying the properties of [CTA][TFSI]-P(VDF-HFP) coating layer, self-supporting flexible membranes were prepared. 1.0 g P(VDF-HFP) (purchased from ALDRICH, average Mw ∼ 455,000, average Mn ∼ 110,000, pellets) was dissolved in 5.0 mL NMP. To this solution, [CTA][TFSI] with different mass ratios (0, 10, 30, 50, 70 and 90 wt%) was added and stirred until completely dissolved. The resultant viscous and transparent solutions were evenly cast on the glass plate with a doctor blade (1000 μm) and then dried at 80 °C for 8 h to form a uniform membrane. The membranes after being removed from the glass plate were named as CP-0, CP-10, CP-30, CP-50, CP-70, and CP-90, corresponding to the mass ratios of 0, 10, 30, 50, 70 and 90 wt%, respectively.

Viscous solutions of CP-0 and CP-50 were prepared in accordance with aforementioned procedure and cast on Cu foil (20 μm) by a doctor blade (50 μm). Samples were dried at 80 °C for 8 h to obtain the resultant Li+ traffic controller, named as CPC-0 and CPC-50, corresponding to CP-0 and CP-50, respectively. Then, the [CTA][TFSI]-P(VDF-HFP)@Cu-Li was obtained by depositing Li with 4 mAh cm−2 at 0.2 mA cm−2. These samples were named as CPC-0-Li and CPC-50-Li, corresponding to CPC-0 and CPC-50, respectively. In addition, the Cu-Li was prepared by the same deposition method without the Li+ traffic controller. The electrolyte was 1 M LiTFSI in DOL/DME with a 1:1 vol ratio and 1 wt% LiNO3 as the additive. If not specified, 20 μL of the electrolyte was used in all batteries. Celgard-2400 was used as the separator.

Asymmetric cells, symmetric cells, and full cells were assembled (or disassembled) in an argon-filled glove box. Here, the Cu foil was washed with acetone and air-dried. All Cu foils were subjected to the same treatment process before being used. The LiFePO4 cathode (named as LFP) was prepared by LiFePO4 powder, conductive agent (acetylene black), and binder (polyvinylidene fluoride) with a mass ratio of 8:1:1. The LFP electrodes were obtained by slurry casting method and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Another type of high-mass loading commercial LFP cathode (2.2 mAh cm−2) with a 95 wt% weight ratio of LFP was also utilized. The diameter of all the electrodes was 8 mm. The long-term cycling performance of batteries was tested on the LAND and NEWARE testing systems. The Coulombic efficiency (CE) of Cu, CPC-0, and CPC-50 were tested by the Li||Cu, Li||CPC-0, and Li||CPC-50 asymmetric cell at 1 mA cm−2. Li metal with 1 mAh cm−2 was first deposited on a current collector by a discharging process. Then, the deposited Li was completely stripped by a charging process. The CE was given by the capacity ratio of stripped to the deposited Li. The symmetric cells of Cu-Li||Cu-Li, CPC-0-Li||CPC-0-Li, and CPC-50-Li||CPC-50-Li were tested by different area capacities and currents. For accurately controlling N/P ratio, a Li1-xFePO4 positive electrode was used in this work. Li1-xFePO4 was prepared by removing Li+ from LiFePO4. The amount of Li+ deintercalation from the LiFePO4 determined the matching capacity of the negative electrode. All full cells were set to a ratio of N/P = 1, which was calculated by Li/LiFePO4. For example, when Li1-xFePO4 was obtained from LiFePO4 by removing 1 mAh cm−2 Li+, a negative electrode of 2 mAh cm−2 was prepared to match it. Full cells of Cu-Li||Li1-xFePO4, CPC-0-Li||Li1-xFePO4, and CPC-50-Li||Li1-xFePO4 were characterized at different rates. To test the exchange current density (
j 0
) of different electrodes, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of symmetric cells were measured at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1 from −0.2 to 0.2 V. The Tafel plot was obtained by
lg | i |

All HOMO-LUMO energy calculations were approved using the Gaussian (G09) program and Becke's three-parameter hybrid approach with the Lee-Yang-Parr correlation functional (B3LYP) at the 6-311++G(d,p) level [22].

Finite element simulations were performed by COMSOL Multiphysics software package. The “Tertiary Current Distribution, Nernst-Planck” physics model was employed for the simulations. The constructed area was set as 10 × 20 μm2, in which the top part constituted of the electrolyte (1 M), whereas the bottom region was naturally formed SEI (1 μm) or [CTA][TFSI]-P(VDF-HFP) (2 μm). In addition, three semicircles with a radius of 0.8 μm were constructed to represent Li nuclei. The diffusion coefficients of Li+ for electrolyte, native SEI, and [CTA][TFSI]-P(VDF-HFP) were set as 1 × 10−9 m2/s, 1 × 10−13 m2/s, and 1 × 10−10 m2/s, respectively. Ionic mobilities were determined by the Nernst-Einstein equation. The dynamic expression type was Butler-Volmer. It is to be noted that this simulations present a simplified version of the electrochemical process and a realistic representation under practical conditions is much more complicated.

Fig. 1 illustrates a schematic diagram of deposits with and without Li+ traffic controller. It employs a two-fold strategy to regulate the Li+ deposition path, where one mechanism involves the self-healing electrostatic shielding, whereas the other is the optimization of SEI with inorganic-rich components. Since the ionic conductivity of optimized SEI is higher than that of naturally formed SEI, it results in the internal Li+ concentration being more uniform. In addition to the Li+ traffic controller protecting SEI from significant volume fluctuations, reduced interfacial fluctuations achieved via homogenous deposition also minimize SEI damage. As a result, the CPC-50-Li electrode remains intact after 20 cycles of operation, as shown in Fig. 1a. In contrast, without the Li+ traffic controller, the electrode is more likely to consists of a nonuniform deposition of Li. This results in the formation of cracks and thick layers of dead Li on the electrode surface after operation for 20 cycles, as shown in Fig. 1b.

The mechanical properties of the membranes with different [CTA][TFSI] mass ratios are shown in Figure S1. The bearable stress of the [CTA][TFSI]-P(VDF-HFP) membranes decreased along with the increasing content of [CTA][TFSI] and the maximum strain was obtained at 50 wt% (CP-50). A large strain is indicative of large plastic deformation ability, which enables CP-50 to adapt to the volume change of Li metal. The ionic conductivity of CTA+ in [CTA][TFSI]-P(VDF-HFP) membranes was tested at room temperature (Figure S2). CP-50 exhibited the highest ionic conductivity, followed by CP-70 that showed a value close to CP-50 (Fig. 2 a). This result demonstrates that membranes with low concentrations of [CTA][TFSI], such as CP-10 and CP-30, cannot effectively promote segmental polymer chain mobility. Whereas membranes with high concentrations of [CTA][TFSI], such as CP-90, will constrain the segmental polymer chain mobility [23]. As the main component of the Li+ traffic controller that plays a regulating role on the Li+, good conductivity of CTA+ can ensure that it reaches the site that is prone to dendritic formation in a timely manner. Therefore, an optimal proportion of 50 wt% [CTA][TFSI] (CP-50) was used to prepare the Li+ traffic controller. P(VDF-HFP) without [CTA][TFSI] (CP-0) was selected as the control sample for comparison studies.

It is useful to ascertain the nature of interactions between [CTA][TFSI] and P(VDF-HFP). For this, 1H NMR spectra of CP-50, [CTA][TFSI], and CP-0 were obtained, as shown in Fig. 2b, c, and Fig. 2e-g. In the 1H NMR spectra, resonance peaks of protons on the quaternary ammonium group and P(VDF-HFP) showed slight shifts. These changes indicate the presence of hydrogen bonding and ion–dipole interactions [24,25]. The chemical bonding states of CP-50 and CP-0 were further elucidated by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), as shown in Fig. 2h and Table S1. Obvious stretching and bending vibration peaks of methyl groups can be found after adding [CTA][TFSI] in CP-0. In addition, the stretching vibration peaks of C-F in CP-50 significantly shifted to low frequencies (1066 cm−1 to 1047 cm−1, 1228 cm−1 to 1194 cm−1), owing to hydrogen bonding and ion–dipole interactions. The shift of C-F from 1169 cm−1 (CP-0) to 1180 cm−1 (CP-50) may be caused by the change of electron distribution in the molecule. Moreover, the new peak at 1135 cm−1 in CP-50 originates from [CTA][TFSI] [26]. The scattering profile of the small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) experiment did not exhibit any diffraction peaks, revealing that the charges are uniformly distributed in CP-50 and nanophase segregation is absent (Fig. 2d) [23,25]. The results of electrochemical stabilities of CP-0 and CP-50 reveal that the electrochemical stabilities of CP-0 and CP-50 can reach up to 4.70 and 4.74 V vs. Li+/Li respectively, as shown in Fig. 2i. This indicates that the addition of [CTA][TFSI] does not change the electrochemical stability of the membranes. The swelling tests of CP-0 and CP-50 reveal a 9.2 % and 22.1 % increase in their weight after soaking in the electrolyte, respectively. The higher swelling may be attributed to an increase in the amorphous state of the polymer [24]. Additionally, differences in membrane morphology also affect the swelling. CP-0 has a Li+ transference number of 0.26 (Figure S3), while for CP-50 it is 0.73 (Fig. 2j). A high Li+ transference number of CP-50 can ensure the rapid transport of Li+.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Interfacial chemistry and morphology of electrode
ce:section.ce:para: XPS is conducted to study the composition of SEI. All electrodes have a capacity of 4 mAh cm−2. The C 1s, F 1s, and S 2p spectra of Cu-Li and CPC-50-Li are shown in Fig. 3 a and b. CC (284.8 eV, C 1s), CO (286.6 eV, C 1s), and CO (288.8 eV, C 1s) found before the etching mainly represent the organic species on the surfaces of two electrodes. The CN (285.9 eV, C 1s) peak of CPC-50-Li may be caused by the [CTA][TFSI] that contains the ammonium group (Fig. 3b). C-Fx (688.1 eV, F 1s), Li-F (684.8 eV, F 1s), and SO4 2− (169.13 eV and 170.35 eV, S 2p) are also observed on two initial surfaces, which are derived from anions [27,28]. In addition, a small quantity of SO3 2− (166.7 eV and 167.9 eV, S 2p) was tested on the Cu-Li surface as well, while OS = O (167.8 eV and 169.1 eV, S 2p), and Li-S (160.4 eV and 161.7 eV, S 2p) are observed on CPC-50-Li electrode surface. After sputtering, Li2CO3 (290.1 eV, C 1s), SO4 2−, SO3 2−, Li-S, and Li-F become the dominant peaks in C 1s, F 1s, and S 2p of Cu-Li respectively, while the Li2CO3, Li-F and Li-S constitute the major peaks on the CPC-50-Li. Furthermore, O 1s and N 1s XPS spectra reveal that CPC-50-Li is rich in Li2O, Li3N, and LixNOy (Figure S4). To further highlight the benefits of this Li+ traffic controller for optimizing the SEI, the XPS analysis results of the CPC-0-Li were compared, as shown in Figure S5. SEI compositions of CPC-0-Li are found to be organic-rich and.

are almost devoid of LiF and Li2S. Inorganic-rich compositions with Li2O, LiF, Li2S, Li3N, and LixNOy in CPC-50-Li indicate that the [CTA][TFSI] optimizes the compositions of naturally formed SEI. For exploring the optimization mechanism, the HOMO/LUMO energy levels of LiTFSI and [CTA][TFSI] were calculated (Fig. 3c). The results show that [CTA][TFSI] has a lower LUMO energy (−2.2 eV) than LiTFSI (−1.5 eV), indicating that [CTA][TFSI] has a better ability to capture electrons than LiTFSI. A smaller HOMO-LUMO energy gap implies that the [CTA][TFSI] has a faster electron transmission [29]. Hence, TFSI− of [CTA][TFSI] has a higher tendency to decompose to optimize the SEI, and some decomposed components of TFSI− were found on the surface of the Li+ traffic controller. The reduction and oxidation behaviors of LiTFSI and [CTA][TFSI] were further investigated using the cyclic voltammetry method, as shown in Fig. 3d. CPC-50 shows a peak at 1.43 V corresponding to the reduction of anions, while the other two peaks at 0.84 V and 0.27 V are attributed to the decomposition of solvent [30]. In contrast, the reduction of anions on Cu is at 0.99 V and the decomposition of solvent is located at 0.68 V and 0.18 V. The reduction peak of anions in CPC-0 is not obvious (Figure S6), which highlights the importance of [CTA][TFSI] in the formation of inorganic-rich SEI again.

The morphology of the samples was analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Figure S7a shows the initial cross-sectional morphology of Cu. A film (CP-0) with a thickness of ∼1.4 μm is coated on the Cu (Figure S7b). Similarly, CP-50 film with ∼2 μm thickness is coated on the Cu (Figure S7c). Figure S8a, d, and g show the surface morphologies of the pure Cu and Cu-Li. When Cu was coated on CP-0, the surface morphology became uniform but showed many tiny folds (Figure S8b and e). After depositing Li metal, the CP-0 coating layer exhibited some obvious cracks, as shown in Figure S8h. The SEM images of CP-50 coated on Cu show that [CTA][TFSI] prompts P(VDF-HFP) to form spherulites (Figure S8c and f). The morphological difference can be explained by the ion–dipole interactions between [CTA][TFSI] and the polar polymer chains [31]. Spherulites are enlarged after depositing Li metal, but no cracks are generated on the Li+ traffic controller, as shown in Figure S8i. Digital images of Cu-Li, CPC-0-Li, and CPC-50-Li reveal the macroscopic morphology, as shown in Figure S9. It can be observed that CPC-50-Li exhibits a smoother surface as compared to Cu-Li and CPC-0-Li.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Performance of asymmetric and symmetric cells
ce:section.ce:para: The nucleation overpotentials of Li deposition on Cu, CPC-0, and CPC-50 were investigated, as shown in Fig. 4 a. The nucleation overpotentials of Li on Cu, CPC-0, and CPC-50 were obtained to be 11, 30, and 17 mV at 0.2 mA cm−2, respectively. The higher overpotentials of CPC-0 and CPC-50 may be attributed to the compact contact between the coating layer and the Cu foil, which creates resistance to the nucleation process. Fig. 4b shows that the average CE of CPC-50 reached up to 98.3 % for 80 cycles, while Cu and CPC-0 collapsed on 50 and 30 cycles, respectively. Although the initial nucleation dynamic of Cu is relatively good, the stable CE of CPC-50 indicates that it has better lithium retention capability. The symmetric cells of Cu-Li and CPC-0-Li exhibit substantial voltage fluctuation after only 350 h (175 cycles) and 150 h (75 cycles), respectively, at 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2. This result could be explained by the formation of “dead” Li after repeated Li deposition/dissolution (Fig. 4d). In contrast, the symmetric cell of CPC-50-Li demonstrates the best cycling performance (610 h, 305 cycles). A detailed comparison of voltage profiles of the first 5 h is also shown in Figure S10. A stable voltage hysteresis is detected in CPC-50-Li||CPC-50-Li (∼30 mV), while sustained fluctuations are observed in Cu-Li||Cu-Li and CPC-0-Li||CPC-0-Li within the potential range of 50 mV to 85 mV and 100 mV to 175 mV, respectively. To compare the reaction kinetics at the interface of the Cu-Li, CPC-0-Li, and CPC-50- Li electrodes, the exchange current densities of the electrodes were measured. The LSV curves and Tafel plots are shown in Figure S11. The exchange current density of the CPC-50-Li electrode was found to be 2.14 mA cm−2, which was higher than Cu-Li (1.7 mA cm−2) and CPC-0-Li electrodes (1.58 mA cm−2), as shown in Fig. 4c. According to the Butler-Volmer equation, a higher exchange current density can reduce the electrochemical polarization of the CPC-50-Li electrode, which is in accordance with the symmetric cell potential profiles [13,32]. The optimized SEI of CPC-50-Li is enriched with inorganic components such as Li2S. The ionic conductivity of Li2S is reported to be ∼10−5 S cm−1, which is higher than that of LiF (3 × 10−9 S cm−1) and lithium carbonate (10−8 S cm−1) [33]. Furthermore, inorganic components enhance the stability of SEI and prevent the parasitic reaction. Therefore, the exchange current density of the CPC-50-Li electrode is significantly higher than that of the Cu-Li electrode, which is covered by low ionic conductivity products. As a result, the CPC-50-Li electrode exhibits significantly improved kinetics and stability. Fig. 4e compares the electrochemical performance of symmetric cells between this study and other reports [11,23,34–36]. Despite the initial amount of Li and electrolyte for symmetric cell being lower in this work compared to other state-of-the-art symmetric cells, a better performance is obtained.

To further understand the mechanism of the Li+ traffic controller for promoting uniform deposition, finite element analysis of Li+ concentration distribution was simulated by the COMSOL Multiphysics package. The simulated geometric diagram and detail are shown in Figure S12, and the initial Li+ concentration distribution is shown in Figure S13a and b. In the simulation schematic, lines with arrows represent the Li+ flux, and the black lines at the bottom represent the boundary between the native SEI or traffic controller and the electrolyte. The colormap depicts the concentration of Li+, blue being low concentrations and red being higher concentrations, represented by the scale bar in Fig. 4f-g. The simulation results at t = 2 s show that the Li+ flux deflects on the surface of Cu-Li and accumulates at a certain point (Fig. 4f and Figure S13c). The valley between the two Li peaks has a low Li+ content, while a large amount of Li+ is concentrated at the Li peak. Uneven Li+ deposition leads to the improper allocation of Li+ concentration. In contrast, no significant deflection of Li flux is observed in the simulation of CPC-50-Li (Fig. 4g and Figure S13d) due to the traffic controller. The valley between the Li peaks shows a smaller concentration difference from the upper interface. The distribution of Li+ concentration is much more uniform than Cu-Li due to better regulation of Li+ concentration owing to the intervention of the coating layer.

A full cell with N/P = 1 was assembled by delithiated-LiFePO4 (Li1-xFePO4) cathode and Cu-Li, CPC-0-Li, and CPC-50-Li anode, as shown in Fig. 5 a. The delithiated curves of LiFePO4 and deposition curves of Cu-Li, CPC-0-Li, and CPC-50-Li are shown in Figure S14 and Figure S15. The cycle performance of full cells was measured by first discharging and then charging. The rate capability of Cu-Li||Li1-xFePO4, CPC-0-Li||Li1-xFePO4 and CPC-50-Li||Li1-xFePO4 full cells at current densities from 1C, 2C, 4C, 8C to 4C, 2C, 1C are compared in Fig. 5b. The charge/discharge profiles of the 70th cycle of the three full cells at 1C are shown in Fig. 5c. It can be observed that the specific capacity of CPC-0-Li||Li1-xFePO4 full cell in the rate cycling shows an obvious attenuation. Although the performance of Cu-Li||Li1-xFePO4 is much better than that of CPC-0-Li||Li1-xFePO4, the specific capacity exhibits a certain extent of decline under the high rate. In contrast, in the CPC-50-Li||Li1-xFePO4 full cell, the specific capacity was found to be the best maintained among all the three kinds of full cells under the high rate. Additionally, almost no decay was observed in the specific capacity when it returned to 1C. Fig. 5d and e show the long cyclability of CPC-50-Li||Li1-xFePO4 full cell with an area capacity of 0.77 mAh cm−2 at 1C. The voltage plateau gap of charge and discharge was steadily maintained during the cycling process. The CPC-50-Li||Li1-xFePO4 full cell had a high area capacity of 2.2 mAh cm−2 over 200 cycles at 0.5C, as shown in Fig. 5f and Figure S16. Moreover, the polarization voltage of charge and discharge greatly reduced and was found to be stable, as shown in Fig. 5g. The lower discharge capacity of the first cycle shown in Fig. 5d and 5f is likely caused by the remaining Li+ of Li1-xFePO4. Li1-xFePO4 is prepared by delithiating Li+ of LiFePO4 without aging before assembling. In general, it is difficult to completely remove the Li+ during the delithiated process, especially with a charging cutoff voltage of 4 V. These remaining Li+ are often located in the inner region of the Li1-xFePO4 particle. Therefore, the battery using Li1-xFePO4 reaches the cutoff voltage in advance during the first cycle discharge, resulting in a decreased capacity. When the second cycle is in progress, the discharge can return to normal capacity, which causes an increase in discharge capacity initially. After a stable cycle of the battery for a while, a decrease in the capacity is observed again. This is caused by the insufficient amount of active lithium available on the negative electrode. The good performance of CPC-50-Li anode in the full cell is attributed to the presence of the Li+ traffic controller [CTA][TFSI]-P(VDF-HFP), which can control the deposition paths of Li+ and optimize SEI components and enhance the cyclability by protecting SEI from the crack. However, Cu-Li is constantly confronted with a large fluctuation of the electrode surface, which has a greater tendency for the formation of dead Li and consumption of electrolyte, resulting in poor cyclic stability. Table S2 compares the electrochemical performance of full cells between this study and other reports, which illustrates the advancement of CPC-50-Li and validates the feasibility of the proposed Li+ traffic controller.

In summary, a versatile strategy to regulate the Li+ deposition is realized by the use of a Li+ traffic controller [CTA][TFSI]-P(VDF-HFP), which can optimize and protect SEI for constructing a stable interface. The electrode–electrolyte interface stabilization significantly reduces Li metal waste and lengthens the life of the thin Li anode. XPS characterization and HOMO/LUMO calculations reveal the critical role of [CTA][TFSI] in promoting the cleavage of TFSI− to generate an inorganic-rich SEI. Finite element simulations using COMSOL Multiphysics further demonstrates that the Li+ traffic controller regulates the Li+ flux and concentration distribution. Moreover, results of exchange current density indicate that the optimized SEI is advantageous for enhancing the reaction kinetics. As a result, even under strict conditions with an ultra-low N/P ratio, the significant benefits of [CTA][TFSI]-P(VDF-HFP) Li+ traffic controller can result in full cells with better cyclability. This work promotes the practical potential of thin Li metal batteries with a low N/P ratio.

Mengli Tao: Writing – original draft, Data curation. Guangyuan Du: Investigation. Wenwu Zou: Conceptualization. Jiaqi Cao: Visualization. Wei Li: Visualization. Guangli Zheng: Methodology. Zhenxing Liang: Project administration. Zhiming Cui: Data curation. Li Du: Data curation. Huiyu Song: Writing – review & editing, Funding acquisition.
